Data * Analysis + R

Blog of Daniel Marcelino

Blog Posts

  • Yet the Worst Olympic Chart August 06, 2016 The Olympics barely began but we already have the worst chart winner.
  • Calculating Memory Requirements July 20, 2016 A post about size and memory requirements that a computer must have to deal with a data frame.
  • What is reproducible research? June 23, 2016 This entry states a minimalist view of reproducible research: The capacity of repeating an experiment in any place with any person.
  • R packaging industry close-up: How fast are we growing? June 18, 2016 This entry brings in a quick analysis of the rate R packages have been published in the official repository (CRAN).
  • Everything Ends on Wednesday February 12, 2016 This post approaches HIV incidence rate among Brazilians and simulates several levels of HIV infection.
  • The Star Wars Grossing War January 11, 2016 This post shows how to scrap data from 'boxofficemojo.com', then to clean and visualize the data.
  • Gender Effect in Conference Talks December 22, 2015 The entry discuss a study that finds strong gender effects in conference talks
  • Venezuelan Parliamentary Election: What do the Polls Say? December 06, 2015 This entry explores the coming legislative election in Venezuela: Government is about to lose the majority.
  • Venezuela's 2015 Parliamentary Elections December 04, 2015 This post shows the tremendous variability from pollster to pollster about the voting intention among Venezuelans.
  • Retrieving Data from Google Books with `ngramr` November 15, 2015 The post explores the Google Ngram Viewer service requested from.
  • Competing views on Argentina's Frontrunner October 30, 2015 This post analyze the very few polls published so far on the Argentina's runoff election. Overall, polls seem to be telling two distinct histories.
  • House Effects in Argentinian polling October 25, 2015 This post presents the estimated house effects for the main presidential candidates in Argentina, considering more than 115 polls since 2014.
  • Paranormal Distribution October 20, 2015 This is funny.
  • A Talk About Campaign Finance in Brazil October 17, 2015 This post provides some unsolicited comments on the campaign finance issue.
  • Understanding Margin of Error for Small Populations October 13, 2015 This post discusses margin of error, gives some theoretical reasons and apply them to a real poll.
  • The Butterfly Curve October 07, 2015 This post shows the implementation of the butterfly curve equation in R, and its output plot produced with ggplot2.
  • Isn't sad that all that matters in an election is the candidate's height? September 15, 2015 This post discusses the importance of candidates' stature in US presidential elections.
  • The Greek thing July 04, 2015 This post uses Bayesian methods to analyze polling data of Greek Referendum.
  • R has a new consortium, should we celebrate? July 02, 2015 This post presents some ideas about the new R Consortium.
  • Frente Amplio Winnability November 14, 2014 This entry briefly analyzes the population of polls for the coming elections in Uruguay.
  • Runoff in Uruguay: FA is expected to win a third mandate November 14, 2014 This entry briefly analyzes the population of polls for the coming election in Uruguay: Voters will decide between FA and PN in a short runoff election.
  • A Bit More Fragmented October 06, 2014 This entry discusses the legislative elections in Brazil, which turned out to produce one of the most fragmented parliament in the world.
  • Yep. He made it; country voted No September 19, 2014 This post talks big about my last predictions for the Referendum in Scotland.
  • Bayes says `don't worry` about Scotland's Referendum September 17, 2014 This post uses Bayesian methods to show the anti-independence vote has an overwhelming advantage over the pro-independence side.
  • Discontinuity Bayesian Forecasting July 16, 2014 The post presents some ideas of a more robust Bayesian linear filtering models to forecast Brazilian subnational elections.
  • Parallel computing in R July 01, 2014 This post shows parallel computing is incredibly useful, but not every thing worths being distributed across as many cores as possible.
  • Do you believe in World Cup superstition? June 24, 2014 If you believe in supernatural causality, you will love what the numbers say about the World Cup in Brazil.
  • Got Bootstrap? June 23, 2013 This post discuss some of the techniques of bootstrapping in R, presented in the new book by Michael Chernick and Robert LaBudde.
  • Parallel Processing: When does it worth? May 29, 2013 This post shows parallel computing is incredibly useful, but not every thing worths being distributed across as many cores as possible.
  • Showing Explained Variance in Multilevel Models October 03, 2011 The post shows a way of displaying explained variance of multilevel models using line chart.
